verses.text: Then the LORD said to Joshua, “Do not be afraid or discouraged. Take all the fighting men with you, and go up to Ai. See, I have handed the king of Ai, his people, his city, and his land over to you.
verses.comment: The phrase 'Do not be afraid or discouraged' echoes earlier reassurance to Joshua (Josh. 1:9).

verses.text: You shall do to Ai and its king just as you did to Jericho and its king. Only you may take its plunder and livestock for yourselves. Set an ambush against the city, behind it.”
verses.comment: Contrasts with Jericho, where they were not allowed to take plunder (Josh. 6:17-19).

verses.text: So Joshua and all the fighting men got ready to go up to Ai. Joshua chose thirty thousand mighty men of valor and sent them out by night.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts say 'five thousand'; the Masoretic Text says 'thirty thousand.'

verses.text: He commanded them, saying, “See, you are to set an ambush against the city, behind it. Do not go very far from the city, and all of you be ready.
verses.comment: Faithfully conveys Joshua’s tactical command.

verses.text: I and all the people who are with me will approach the city. When they come out against us, as they did before, we will flee from them.
verses.comment: Refers to the previous defeat in Josh. 7:5.

verses.text: They will come out after us until we have lured them away from the city, for they will say, ‘They are fleeing from us, just as before.’ So we will flee before them.
verses.comment: Explains the ambush tactic used.

verses.text: Then you shall rise up from the ambush and take possession of the city, for the LORD your God will give it into your hand.
verses.comment: A declaration of confidence in God’s promise.

verses.text: And when you have seized the city, you shall set it on fire. Do as the LORD has commanded. See, I have given you orders.”
verses.comment: Echoes instructions given at Jericho.

verses.text: So Joshua sent them out, and they went to the place of the ambush, and stayed between Bethel and Ai, to the west of Ai. But Joshua spent that night among the people.
verses.comment: Geographical note: Bethel was near Ai.

verses.text: Joshua rose early in the morning and mustered the people. He, together with the elders of Israel, went up before the people to Ai.
verses.comment: ‘Rose early in the morning’ is a common phrase in Joshua’s narrative.

verses.text: And all the fighting men who were with him went up and drew near before the city, and camped to the north of Ai, with a valley between them and Ai.
verses.comment: Details the military positioning.

verses.text: He took about five thousand men and set them in ambush between Bethel and Ai, to the west of the city.
verses.comment: There is debate if this group is part of the initial 30,000 or an additional force.

verses.text: So they stationed the people, all the army that was to the north of the city, and the rear guard to the west. But Joshua went that night into the valley.
verses.comment: Joshua’s movement shows leadership and oversight.

verses.text: When the king of Ai saw this, he and all the men of the city hurried out early to meet Israel in battle at a certain place before the Arabah. He did not know that there was an ambush against him behind the city.
verses.comment: ‘The Arabah’ refers to the Jordan Rift Valley.

verses.text: Joshua and all Israel pretended to be beaten before them and fled toward the wilderness.
verses.comment: The tactic of feigned retreat is described.

verses.text: So all the people who were in the city were called together to pursue them, and they pursued Joshua and were drawn away from the city.
verses.comment: All defense was abandoned.

verses.text: Not a man was left in Ai or Bethel who did not go out after Israel. They left the city open and pursued Israel.
verses.comment: Bethel's involvement is implied as well.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Joshua, “Stretch out the javelin that is in your hand toward Ai, for I will give it into your hand.” So Joshua stretched out the javelin in his hand toward the city.
verses.comment: The gesture signified military action and God’s command.

verses.text: And as soon as he stretched out his hand, the men in ambush rose quickly out of their place and ran to the city. They entered and captured it, and hurried to set the city on fire.
verses.comment: The obedience and speed of the ambush force is emphasized.

verses.text: When the men of Ai looked back, they saw, behold, the smoke of the city rising up to the sky, and they had no power to flee this way or that, because the people who had fled to the wilderness turned back against the pursuers.
verses.comment: Describes being trapped between two Israelite forces.

verses.text: When Joshua and all Israel saw that the ambush had captured the city and that the smoke was going up from the city, then they turned back and struck down the men of Ai.
verses.comment: Israel launches the counterattack.

verses.text: The others came out from the city against them, so they were caught in the middle, with Israel on both sides. They struck them down, leaving none who survived or escaped.
verses.comment: Annihilation of Ai’s fighting men is stressed.

verses.text: But they captured the king of Ai alive and brought him to Joshua.
verses.comment: The king is reserved for public execution.

verses.text: When Israel had finished killing all the inhabitants of Ai in the open country, in the wilderness where they had pursued them, and all had fallen by the edge of the sword, all Israel returned to Ai and struck it with the edge of the sword.
verses.comment: Reiterates the total destruction.

verses.text: And all who fell that day, both men and women, were twelve thousand, all the people of Ai.
verses.comment: The number is emphasized to underline the scale.

verses.text: But Joshua did not draw back his hand, with which he stretched out the javelin, until he had devoted all the inhabitants of Ai to destruction.
verses.comment: Joshua’s upheld weapon signifies persistent obedience.

verses.text: Only the livestock and the plunder of that city Israel took as their own spoil, according to the word of the LORD which he commanded Joshua.
verses.comment: Contrast to Jericho, where plunder was forbidden.

verses.text: So Joshua burned Ai and made it a heap forever, a desolation to this day.
verses.comment: Archaeological remains of Ai may correspond to this.

verses.text: He hanged the king of Ai on a tree until evening. At sunset Joshua commanded, and they took his body down from the tree and threw it at the entrance of the gate of the city and raised a great heap of stones over it, which stands to this day.
verses.comment: Removal at sunset obeys Deut. 21:23.

verses.text: Then Joshua built an altar to the LORD, the God of Israel, on Mount Ebal,
verses.comment: Obedience to the Law after victory.

verses.text: just as Moses the servant of the LORD had commanded the Israelites, as it is written in the Book of the Law of Moses, ‘an altar of uncut stones, on which no iron tool has been used.’ And they offered burnt offerings on it to the LORD and sacrificed peace offerings.
verses.comment: Repeats Mosaic legislation for altars.

verses.text: And there, in the presence of the Israelites, he wrote on the stones a copy of the Law of Moses, which he had written.
verses.comment: Emphasizes literacy and covenant reminder.

verses.text: All Israel, with their elders, officers, and judges, stood on both sides of the ark before the Levitical priests who carried the ark of the covenant of the LORD—stranger as well as native born—half of them in front of Mount Gerizim and half of them in front of Mount Ebal, as Moses the servant of the LORD had commanded earlier, that they should bless the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Foreigners and native Israelites alike were present, following Moses’ instructions.

verses.text: Afterward, he read all the words of the law, the blessing and the curse, just as written in the Book of the Law.
verses.comment: Both blessings and curses were recited, as previously commanded.

verses.text: There was not a word of all that Moses had commanded that Joshua did not read before all the assembly of Israel, including the women, the little ones, and the foreigners who lived among them.
verses.comment: Explicit mention of all groups present, non-inclusive but literal.
